answers.author: Maxwell Moline
answers.text:
Hello Brenda, 
This excerpt from PM Magazine discusses conflicts of interest among Planning Commissioners, and ways to combat them. Sometimes, new commissioners could use an orientation on conflicts of interest. It also discusses the importance of streamlining the process to avoid too much time consumption. 
http://webapps.icma.org/pm/9102/public/ethics.cfm?author=&title=Ethics 
The City of Brunswick’s planning commission relies on individual proposals of planning commissioners to vote on commission decisions, with the requirement of a comprehensive proposal for each project. 
http://icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/4307 
The City of Windsor Heights also has a Commission with individual recommendations, with very clear policies on levels of detail in reports. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/4772/City_of_Windsor_Heights_Citizens_Guide_to_the_Plan_and_Zoning_Commission 
A number of places designate individuals or committees to oversee such approvals in person. Here is an example of each: 
Mountain View Community Development Director:  http://bookstore.icma.org/freedocs/mlgs/jobdescriptionCommunity_Development_Director.pdf 
Central Point Building Department: 
http://icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/12832 
Let us know if this helps, and if you need any more information. 
Max Moline 
Knowledge Network Intern 
ICMA

author: Brenda Vinall-Mogel
text:
I am from a very small town and we are writing a subdivision Ord.  In it I said that all Planning Commissioners would visit the site prior to either approval or not of the subdivision plan.
The other Planning Commissioners feel they just need to send a representative and make their decision off of the opinion of one person or they might just go off of the map provided.
I said, no we all needed to go to all sites as it provides consistency and validity to any determination about future subdivisions and let everyone on the commission ask reasonable questions since all member were there.  
As we are a small town besides the above, I feel not having everyone go to the possible future subdivision site might cause future problems through the publics perception of consistency of site visits.
I have looked through my ethics book and cannot find an example to show the other commissioners.
Am I wrong?
title: Site Visitations
